div.p: A TRIP TO SCARBOROUGH A COMEDY.
A TRIP TO SCARBOROUGH. A COMEDY. AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL IN DRURY LANE.
ALTERED FROM Vanbrugh's Relapſe; or, Virtue in Danger.
LONDON. Printed for G. WILKIE, No. 71, St. Paul's Church-yard. MDCCLXXXI.

lg.l: WHAT various transformations we remark,
From Eaſt Whitechapel to the Weſt Hyde-park!
Men, women, children, houſes, ſigns, and faſhions,
State, ſtage, trade, taſte, the humours and the paſſions;
Th' Exchange, 'Change alley, whereſoe'er your ranging,
Court, city, country, all are chang'd, or changing;
The ſtreets ſometime ago, were pav'd with ſtones,
Which, aided by a hackney coach, half broke your bones.
The pureſt lovers then indulg'd no bliſs;
They run great hazard if they ſtole a kiſs—

l.hi: One chaſte ſalute—the Damſel cry'd, O fye!

lg.l: As they approach'd, ſlap went the coach awry,
—Poor Sylvia got a bump, and Damon a black eye.
But now weak nerves in hackney coaches roam,
And the cramm'd glutton ſnores unjolted home:
Of former times that poliſh'd thing a Beau,
Is metamorphos'd now, from top to toe;
Then the full flaxen wig, ſpread o'er the ſhoulders,
Conceal'd the ſhallow head from the beholders!
But now the whole's revers'd—each fop appears,
Cropp'd, and trimm'd up—expoſing head and ears;
The buckle then it's modeſt limits knew—
Now, like the ocean, dreadful to the view,
Hath broke it's bounds, and ſwallows up the ſhoe;
The wearer's foot, like his once fine eſtate,
Is almoſt loſt, th' incumbrance is ſo great.
Ladies may ſmile—are they not in the plot?
The bounds of nature have not they forgot?
Were they deſign'd to be, when put together,
Made up, like ſhuttlecocks, of cork and feather?
Their pale fac'd grand-mama's appear'd with grace,
When dawning bluſhes roſe upon the face;
No bluſhes now their once lov'd ſtation ſeek,
The foe is in poſſeſſion of the cheek!
No head of old, too high in feather'd ſtate,
Hinder'd the fair to paſs the loweſt gate;
A church to enter now, they muſt be bent,
If ev'n they ſhould try th' experiment.
As change thus circulates throughout the nation,
Some plays may juſtly call for alteration;
At leaſt to draw ſome ſlender cov'ring o'er
That graceleſs wit,And Van wants Grace, who never wanted Wit. POPE. which was too bare before:
Thoſe writers well and wiſely uſe their pens,
Who turn our Wantons into Magdalens;
And howſoever wicked wits revile 'em,
We hope to find in you, their Stage Aſylum.

body.head: A TRIP TO SCARBOROUGH, A COMEDY.

div.head: SCENE I. the Hall of an Inn.
div.stage: Enter YOUNG FASHION and LORY—Poſtillion following with a Portmanteau.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: LORY, pay the poſt-boy, and take the portmanteau.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Faith, ſir, we had better let the poſt-boy take the portmanteau and pay himſelf.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Why ſure there's ſomething leſt in it.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p:
Not a rag, upon my honour, ſir—we eat the
laſt of your wardrobe at Newmalton—and if we had had twenty miles farther to go, our next meal muſt have been off the cloak-bag.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Why 'ſdeath it appears full.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Yes, ſir—I made bold to ſtuff it with hay, to ſave appearances, and look like baggage.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: What the devil ſhall I do!—harkee, boy, what's the chaiſe?

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: Thirteen ſhillings, pleaſe your honour.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Can you give me change for a guinea?

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: O yes, ſir.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Soh, what will he do now?—Lord, ſir, you had better let the boy be paid below.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Why, as you ſay, Lory, I believe it will be as well.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Yes, yes; tell them to diſcharge you below, honeſt friend.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: Pleaſe your honour, there are the turnpikes too.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Aye, aye; the turnpikes by all means.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: And I hope your honour will order me ſomething for myſelf.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: To be ſure, bid them give you a crown.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Yes, yes—my maſter doesn't care what you charge them—ſo get along you—

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.p: Your honour promiſed to ſend the hoſtler—

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: P'ſhaw! damn the hoſtler—would you impoſe upon the gentleman's generoſity?— (Puſhes him out)—A raſcal, to be ſo curſt ready with his change!

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Why faith, Lory, he had near pos'd me.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Well, ſir, we are arrived at Scarborough, not worth a guinea!—I hope you'll own yourſelf a happy man—You have outliv'd all your cares.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: How ſo, ſir?

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Why you have nothing left to take care of.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Yes, ſirrah, I have myſelf and you to take care of ſtill.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Sir, if you could prevail with ſome-body elſe to do that for you, I fancy we might both fare the better for't—But now, ſir, for my Lord Foppington, your elder brother.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Damn my eldeſt brother!

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: With all my heart; but get him to redeem your annuity however.—Look you, ſir, you muſt wheedle him, or you muſt ſtarve.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Look you, ſir, I will neither wheedle him nor ſtarve.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Why what will you do then?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Cut his throat, or get ſome one to do it for me.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Gad-ſo, ſir, I'm glad to find I was not ſo we I acquainted with the ſtrength of your conſcience as with the weakneſs of your purſe.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Why, art thou ſo impenetrable a blockhead as to believe he'll help me with a farthing?

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Not if you treat him de baut en bas as you uſed to do.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Why how would'ſt have me treat him?

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Like a trout—tickle him.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: I can't flatter.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Can you ſtarve?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: I can't—Good-bye t'ye, ſir.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Stay—thou'lt diſtract me. But who comes here—my old friend, Colonel Townly?
My dear Colonel, I am rejoiced to meet you here.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Dear Tom, this is an unexpected pleaſure—what, are you come to Scarbro' to be preſent at your brother's wedding?

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Ah, ſir, if it had been his funeral, we ſhould have come with pleaſure.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: What, honeſt Lory, are you with your maſter ſtill?

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, I have been ſtarving with him ever ſince I ſaw your honour laſt.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Why, Lory is an attach'd rogue; there's no getting rid of him.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: True, ſir, as my maſter ſays, there's no ſeducing me from his ſervice, 'till he's able to pay me my wages. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Go, go, ſir—and take care of the baggage.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Yes, ſir—the baggage!—O Lord!—I ſuppoſe, ſir, I muſt charge the landlord to be very particular where he ſtows this.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Get along, you raſcal. [Exit Lory, with the Portmanteau.
But, Colonel, are you acquainted with my propoſed ſiſter-in-law?

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p:
Only by character—her father, Sir Tunbelly Clumſey, lives within a quarter of a mile of this place, in a lonely old houſe, which nobody comes
near. She never goes abroad, nor ſees company at home; to prevent all misfortunes, ſhe has her breeding within doors; the parſon of the pariſh teaches her to play upon the dulcimer; the clerk to ſing, her nurſe to dreſs, and her father to dance:—in ſhort, nobody has free admiſſion there but our old acquaintance, Mother Coupler, who has procured your brother this match, and is, I believe, a diſtant relation of Sir Tunbelly's.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: But is her fortune ſo conſiderable?

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Three thouſand a year, and a good ſum of money independent of her father beſide.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! that my old acquaintance, dame Coupler, could not have thought of me as well as my brother for ſuch a prize.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Egad I wouldn't ſwear that you are too late—his Lordſhip, I know, hasn't yet ſeen the lady, and, I believe, has quarrelled with his patroneſs.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: My dear Colonel, what an idea have you ſtarted?

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Purſue it if you can, and I promiſe you you ſhall have my aſſiſtance; for beſides my natural contempt for his Lordſhip, I have at preſent the enmity of a rival towards him.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: What, has he been addreſſing your old flame, the ſprightly widow Berinthia?

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Faith, Tom, I am at preſent moſt whimſically circumſtanced—I came here near a month ago to meet the lady you mention; but ſhe failing in her promiſe, I, partly from pique, and partly from idleneſs, have been diverting my chagrin by offering up chaſte incenſe to the beauties of Amanda, our friend Loveleſs's wife.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: I have never ſeen her, but have heard her ſpoken of as a youthful wonder of beauty and prudence.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: She is ſo indeed; and Loveleſs being too careleſs and inſenſible of the treaſure he poſſeſſes—my lodging in the ſame houſe has given me a thouſand opportunities of making my aſſiduities acceptable; ſo that in leſs than a fortnight, I began to bear my diſappointment from the widow, with the moſt Chriſtian reſignation.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: And Berinthia has never appear'd?

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: O there's the perplexity; for juſt as I began not to care whether I ever ſaw her again or not, laſt night ſhe arrived.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: And inſtantly reaſſumed her empire.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: No faith—we met—but the lady not condeſcending to giev me any ſerious reaſons for having fool'd me for a month, I left her in a huff.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p:
Well, well, I'll anſwer for't, ſhe'll ſoon reſume her power, eſpecially as friendſhip will prevent
your purſuing the other too far—but my coxcomb of a brother is an admirer of Amanda's too, is he?

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Yes; and I believe is moſt heartily deſpiſed by her—but come with me, and you ſhall ſee her and your old friend Loveleſs.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: I muſt pay my reſpects to his Lordſhip—perhaps you can direct me to his lodgings.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Come with me, I ſhall paſs by it.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: I wiſh you could pay the viſit for me; or could tell me what I ſhould ſay to him.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Say nothing to him—apply yourſelf to his bag, his ſword, his feather, his ſnuff-box; and when you are well with them, deſire him to lend you a thouſand pounds, and I'll engage you proſper.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: 'Sdeath and furies! why was that coxcomb thruſt into the world before me? O Fortune! Fortune! thou art a jilt, by Gad. [Exit

div.head: SCENE II, a Dreſſing Room.
div.stage: Lord FOPPINGTON, in his Night Gown, and LA VAROLE.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p:
Well, 'tis an unſpeakable pleaſure to be a man of quality—ſtrike me dumb!—even the boors of
this Northern ſpa have learn'd the reſpect due to a title—La Varole!

sp.speaker: LA VAROLE.
sp.p: Mi Lor—

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: You han't yet been at Muddy-Moat-Hall to announce my arrival, have you?

sp.speaker: LA VAROLE.
sp.p: Not yet, mi Lor.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Then you need not go till Saturday, [Exit La Va. as I am in no particular haſte to view my intended Spoſa—I ſhall ſacrifice a day or two more to the purſuit of my friend Loveleſs's wife—Amanda is a charming creature—ſtrike me ugly; and if I have any diſcernment in the world, ſhe thinks no leſs of my Lord Foppington.

sp.speaker: LA VAROLE.
sp.p: Mi Lor, de ſhoemaker, de taylor, de hoſier, de ſempſtreſs, de peru, be all ready, if your lordſhip pleaſe to dreſs.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: 'Tis well, admit them.

sp.speaker: LA VAROLE.
sp.p: Hey, Meſſieurs, entrez.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: So, gentlemen, I hope you have all taken pains to ſhew yourſelves maſters in your profeſſions.

sp.speaker: TAYLOR.
sp.p: I think I may preſume to ſay, Sir—

sp.speaker: LA VAROLE.
sp.p: My Lor, you clown you!

sp.speaker: TAYLOR.
sp.p: My Lord, I aſk your Lordſhip's pardon, my Lord. I hope, my Lord, your Lordſhip will pleaſe to own, I have brought your Lordſhip as accompliſhed a ſuit of clothes as ever Peer of England wore, my Lord—will your Lordſhip pleaſe to try 'em now?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Ay; but let my people diſpoſe the glaſſes ſo, that I may ſee myſelf before and behind; for I love to ſee myſelf all round.
sp.stage: (Whilſt he puts on his clothes, enter YOUNG FASHION and LORY.)

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Hey-day! What the devil have we here?—Sure my gentleman's grown a favourite at court, he has got ſo many people at his levee.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Sir, theſe people come in order to make him a favourite at court—they are to eſtabliſh him with the ladies.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Good Heav'n! to what an ebb of taſte are women fallen, that it ſhould be in the power of a laced coat to recommend a gallant to them!

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Sir, Taylors and Hair-dreſſers are now become the bawds of the nation—'tis they that debauch all the women.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Thou ſay'ſt true; for there's that fop now has not, by nature, wherewithal to move a cook maid: and by the time theſe fellows have done with him, egad he ſhall melt down a Counteſs—but now for my reception.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Death and eternal tortures! Sir—I ſay the coat is too wide here by a foot.

sp.speaker: TAYLOR.
sp.p: My Lord, if it had been tighter, 'twould neither have hook'd nor button'd.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Rat the hooks and buttons, Sir, can any thing be worſe than this?—As Gad ſhall jedge me! it hangs on my ſhoulders like a chairman's ſurtout.

sp.speaker: TAYLOR.
sp.p: 'Tis not for me to diſpute your Lordſhip's fancy.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: There, Sir, obſerve what reſpect does.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Reſpect!—D—m him for a coxcomb—but let's accoſt him.—Brother, I'm your humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: O Lard, Tam, I did not expect you in England—Brother, I'm glad to ſee you—but what has brought you to Scarbro' Tam?—Look you, Sir, (to the Taylor) I ſhall never be reconciled to this nauſeous wrapping gown; therefore, pray get me another ſuit with all poſſible expedition; for this is my eternal averſion—Well, but Tam, you don't tell me what has driven you to Scarbro'?—Mrs. Callicoe, are not you of my mind?

sp.speaker: SEMPSTRESS.
sp.p: Directly, my Lord.—I hope your Lordſhip is pleaſed with your ruffles?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: In love with them, ſtab my vitals!—Bring my bill, you ſhall be paid to-morrow.

sp.speaker: SEMPSTRESS.
sp.p: I humbly thank your Lordſhip. [Exit Semp.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Heark thee, ſhoemaker, theſe ſhoes a'nt ugly, but they don't ſit me.

sp.speaker: SHOEMAKER.
sp.p: My Lord, I think they fit you very well.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: They hurt me juſt below the inſtep.

sp.speaker: SHOEMAKER.
sp.p: (feeling his foot) No, my Lord, they don't hurt you there.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: I tell thee they pinch me execrably.

sp.speaker: SHOEMAKER.
sp.p: Why then, my Lord, if thoſe ſhoes pinch you I'll be d—n'd.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Why wilt thou undertake to perſuade me I cannot feel!

sp.speaker: SHOEMAKER.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip may pleaſe to feel what you think fit, but that ſhoe does not hurt you—I think I underſtand my trade.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Now by all that's good and powerful, thou art an incomprehenſible coxcomb—but thou makeſt good ſhoes, and ſo I'll bear with thee.

sp.speaker: SHOEMAKER.
sp.p: My Lord, I have work'd for half the people of quality in this town theſe twenty years, and 'tis very hard I ſhoudn't know when a ſhoe hurts, and when it don't.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Well, prithee be gone about thy buſineſs. Exit Shoe.
Mr. Mendlegs, a word with you. The calves of theſe ſtockings are thicken'd a little too much; thy make my legs look like a porter's.

sp.speaker: MENDLEGS.
sp.p: My Lord, methinks they look mighty well.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Aye, but you are not ſo good a judge of thoſe things as I am—I have ſtudy'd them all my life—therefore pray let the next be the thickneſs of a crown piece leſs.

sp.speaker: MENDLEGS.
sp.p: Indeed, my Lord, they are the ſame kind I had the honour to furniſh your Lordſhip with in town.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Very poſſibly, Mr. Mendlegs; but that was in the beginning of the winter; and you ſhould always remember, Mr. Hoſier, that if you make a Nobleman's ſpring legs as robuſt as his autumnal calves, you commit a manſtrous impropriety, and make no allowance for the fatigues of the winter.

sp.speaker: JEW.
sp.p: I hope, my Lord, thoſe buckles have had the unſpeakable ſatisfaction of being honoured with your Lordſhip's approbation?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Why they are of a pretty fancy; but don't you think them rather of the ſmalleſt?

sp.speaker: JEW.
sp.p: My Lord, they could not well be larger to keep on your Lordſhip's ſhoe.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: My good Sir, you forget that theſe matters are not as they uſed to be: formerly, indeed, the buckle was a ſort of machine, intended to keep on the ſhoe; but the caſe is now quite reverſed, and the ſhoe is of no earthly uſe, but to keep on the buckle.—Now give me my watches, and the buſineſs of the morning will be pretty well over.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Well, Lory, what doſt think on't?—a very friendly reception from a brother after three years abſence!

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Why, Sir, 'tis your own fault—here you have ſtood ever ſince you came in, and have not commended any one thing that belongs to him.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Nor ever ſhall, while they belong to a coxcomb.—Now your people of buſineſs are gone, brother, I hope I may obtain a quarter of an hour's audience of you?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Faith, Tam, I muſt beg you'll excuſe me at this time, for I have an engagement which I would not break for the ſalvation of mankind. Hey!—there!—is my carriage at the door?—You'll excuſe me, brother. [Going.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Shall you be back to dinner?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: As Gad ſhall jedge me, I can't tell, for it is paſſible I may dine with ſome friends at Donner's.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Shall I meet you there? for I muſt needs talk with you.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: That I'm afraid may'nt be quite ſo praper;—for thoſe I commonly eat with are a people of nice converſation; and you know, Tam, your education has been a little at large—but there are other ordinaries in town—very good beef ordinaries—I ſuppoſe, Tam, you can eat beef?—However, dear Tam, I'm glad to ſee thee in England, ſtap my vitals! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Hell and furies! Is this to be borne?

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, I could almoſt have given him a knock o' the pate myſelf.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: 'Tis enough; I will now ſhew you the exceſs of my paſſion, by being very calm.—Come, Lory, lay your loggerhead to mine, and, in cold blood, let us contrive his deſtruction.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Here comes a head, Sir, would contrive it better than us both, if ſhe would but join in the confederacy.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: By this light, Madam Coupler; ſhe ſeems diſſatisfied at ſomething: let us obſerve her.

sp.speaker: COUPLER.
sp.p:
Soh! I am likely to be well rewarded for my ſervices, truly; my ſuſpicions, I find, were but too
juſt—What! refuſe to advance me a paltry ſum, when I am upon the point of making him maſter of a Galloon! But let him look to the conſequences, an ungrateful, narrow-minded coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: So he is, upon my ſoul, old lady: it muſt be my brother you ſpeak of.

sp.speaker: COUPLER.
sp.p: Hah!—ſtripling, how came you here? What, haſt ſpent all, hey? And art thou come to dun his Lordſhip for aſſiſtance?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: No;—I want ſomebody's aſſiſtance to cut his Lordſhip's throat, without the riſque of being hang'd for him.

sp.speaker: COUPLER.
sp.p: Egad, ſirrah, I could help thee to do him almoſt as good a turn without the danger of being burnt in the hand for't.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: How—how, old Miſchief?

sp.speaker: COUPLER.
sp.p: Why you muſt know I have done you the kindneſs to make up a match for your brother.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: I'm very much beholden to you, truly.

sp.speaker: COUPLER.
sp.p: You may before the wedding-day yet: the lady is a great heireſs, the match is concluded, the writings are drawn, and his lordſhip is come hither to put the finiſhing hand to the buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: I underſtand as much.

sp.speaker: COUPLER.
sp.p: Now you muſt know, ſtripling, your brother's a knave.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: COUPLER:
sp.p: He has given me a bond of a thouſand pounds for helping him to his fortune, and has promiſed me as much more in ready money upon the day of the marriage; which, I underſtand by a friend, he never deſigns to pay me; and his juſt now refuſing to pay me a part, is a proof of it. If, therefore, you will be a generous young rogue and ſecure me five thouſand pounds, I'll help you to the lady.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: And how the devil wilt thou do that?

sp.speaker: COUPLER.
sp.p: Without the devil's aid, I warrant thee. Thy brother's face not one of the family ever ſaw; the whole buſineſs has been managed by me, and all the letters go thro' my hands. Sir Tunbelly Clumſey, my relation, (for that's the old gentleman's name) is apprized of his lordſhip's being down here, and expects him to-morrow to receive his daughter's hand; but the Peer, I find, means to bait here a few days longer, to recover the fatigue of his journey, I ſuppoſe. Now you ſhall go to Muddymoat-hall in this place. I'll give you a letter of introduction; and if you don't marry the girl before ſun-ſet, you deſerve to be hang'd before morning.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Agreed, agreed; and for thy reward—

sp.speaker: COUPLER.
sp.p: Well, well;—tho' I warrant thou haſt not a farthing of money in thy pocket now—no—one may ſee it in thy face.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Not a ſouſe, by Jupiter.

sp.speaker: COUPLER.
sp.p: Muſt I advance then?—well, be at my lodgings next door this evening, and I'll ſee what may be done—We'll ſign and ſeal, and when I have given thee ſome farther inſtructions, thou ſhalt hoiſt ſail and be gone. [Exit Coup.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: So, Lory; Providence thou ſeeſt at laſt takes care of merit: we are in a fair way to be great people.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Aye, ſir, if the devil don't ſtep between the cup and the lip, as he uſes to do.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Why, faith, he has play'd me many a damn'd trick to ſpoil my fortune; and, egad, I'm almoſt afraid he's at work about it again now; but if I ſhould tell thee how, thou'dſt wonder at me.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Indeed, ſir, I ſhould not.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: How doſt know?

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Becauſe, ſir, I have wondered at you ſo often, I can wonder at you no more.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: No! what wouldſt thou ſay if a qualm of conſcience ſhould ſpoil my deſign?

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: I would eat my words, and wonder more than ever!

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p:
Why faith, Lory, tho' I am a young Rakehell,
and have play'd many a rogueiſh trick, this is ſo full-grown a cheat, I find I muſt take pains to come up to't—I have ſcruples.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: They are ſtrong ſymptoms of death. If you find they encreaſe, ſir, pray make your will.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: No, my conſcience ſhan't ſtarve me neither, but thus far I'll liſten to it. Before I execute this project, I'll try my brother to the bottom. If he has yet ſo much humanity about him as to aſſiſt me (tho' with a moderate aid) I'll drop my project at his feet, and ſhew him how I can do for him much more than what I'd aſk he'd do for me. This one concluſive trial of him I reſolve to make.—
sp.l: Succeed or fail, ſtill victory's my lot,
If I ſubdue his heart, 'tis well—if not
I will ſubdue my conſcience to my plot.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: HOW do you like theſe lodgings, my dear? For my part, I am ſo well pleas'd with them, I ſhall hardly remove whilſt we ſtay here, if you are ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: I am ſatisfied with every thing that pleaſes you, elſe I had not come to Scarbro' at all.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: O! a little of the noiſe and folly of this place will ſweeten the pleaſures of our retreat; we ſhall find the charms of our retirement doubled when we return to it.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: That pleaſing proſpect will be my chiefeſt entertainment, whilſt, much againſt my will, I engage in thoſe empty pleaſures which 'tis ſo much the faſhion to be fond of.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: I own moſt of them are, indeed, but empty; yet there are delights, of which a private life is deſtitute, which may divert an honeſt man, and be a harmleſs entertainment to a virtuous woman: good muſick is one; and truly, (with ſome ſmall allowance) the plays, I think, may be eſteemed another.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Plays, I muſt confeſs, have ſome ſmall charms, and would have more, would they reſtrain that looſe encouragement to vice, which ſhocks, if not the virtue of ſome women, at leaſt the modeſty of all.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: But, 'till that reformation can be wholly made, 'twould ſurely be a pity to exclude the productions of ſome of our beſt writers for want of a little wholeſome pruning; which might be effected by any one who poſſeſſed modeſty enough to believe that we ſhould preſerve all we can of our deceaſed authors, at leaſt 'till they are outdone by the living ones.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: What do you think of that you ſaw laſt night?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: To ſay truth, I did not mind it much; my attention was for ſome time taken off to admire the workmanſhip of Nature, in the face of a young lady who ſat ſome diſtance from me, ſhe was ſo exquiſitely handſome!

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: So exquiſitely handſome!

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Why do you repeat my words, my dear?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Becauſe you ſeem'd to ſpeak them with ſuch pleaſure, I thought I might oblige you with their echo.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Then you are alarm'd, Amanda?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: It is my duty to be ſo when you are in danger.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: You are too quick in apprehending for me. I view'd her with a world of admiration, but not one glance of love.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Take heed of truſting to ſuch nice diſtinctions. But were your eyes the only things that were inquiſitive? Had I been in your place, my tongue, I fancy, had been curious too. I ſhould have aſk'd her, where ſhe liv'd (yet ſtill without deſign) who was ſhe pray?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Indeed, I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: You will not tell.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: By all that's ſacred then, I did not aſk.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Nor do you know what company was with her?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: I do not; but why are you ſo earneſt?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: I thought I had cauſe.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: But you thought wrong, Amanda; for turn the caſe, and let it be your ſtory; ſhould you come home and tell me you had ſeen a handſome man, ſhould I grow jealous becauſe you had eyes?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: But ſhould I tell you he was exquiſitely ſo, and that I had gazed on him with admiration, ſhould you not think 'twere poſſible I might go one ſtep further, and enquire his name?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: (Aſide.) She has reaſon on her ſide, I have talk'd too much; but I muſt turn off another way. (To her.) Will you then make no difference, Amanda, between the language of our ſex and yours? There is a modeſty reſtrains your tongues, which makes you ſpeak by halves when you commend, but roving flattery gives a looſe to ours, which makes us ſtill ſpeak double what we think. You ſhould not, therefore, in ſo ſtrict a ſenſe, take what I ſaid to her advantage.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Thoſe flights of flattery, ſir, are to our faces only; when women are once out of hearing, you are as modeſt in your commendations as we are; but I ſhan't put you to the trouble of farther excuſes;—if you pleaſe, this buſineſs ſhall reſt here, only give me leave to wiſh, both for your peace and mine, that you may never meet this miracle of beauty more.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: I am content.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Madam, there is a lady at the door in a chair, deſires to know whether your Ladyſhip ſees company? her name is Berinthia.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: O dear!—'tis a relation I have not ſeen theſe five years, pray her to walk in. (Exit Serv.) Here's another beauty for you; ſhe was, when I ſaw her laſt, reckoned extremely handſome.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Don't be jealous now, for I ſhall gaze upon her too.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Ha!—by Heav'ns the very woman!

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: (Saluting Amanda.) Dear Amanda, I did not expect to meet with you in Scarbro'.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Sweet couſin, I'm overjoy'd to ſee you. (To Lov.) Mr. Loveleſs, here's a relation and a friend of mine, I deſire you'll be better acquainted with.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: (Saluting Berinthia.) If my wife never deſires a harder thing, Madam, her requeſt will be eaſily granted.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Sir, my Lord Foppington preſents his humble ſervice to you, and deſires to know how you do. He's at the next door, and if it be not inconvenient to you, he'll come and wait upon you.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Give my compliments to his Lordſhip, and I ſhall be glad to ſee him. (Exit Serv.) If you are not acquainted with his Lordſhip, Madam, you will be entertained with his character.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p:
Now it moves my pity more than my mirth, to
ſee a man whom Nature has made no ſool, be ſo very induſtrious to paſs for an aſs.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: No, there you are wrong, Amanda; you ſhould never beſtow your pity upon thoſe who take pains for your contempt; pity thoſe whom Nature abuſes, never thoſe who abuſe Nature.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Dear Loveleſs, I am your moſt humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: My Lord, I'm your's.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Madam, your Ladyſhip's very humble ſlave.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: My Lord, this lady is a relation of my wife's.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: (Saluting her.) The beautifulleſt race of people upon earth, rat me. Dear Loveleſs, I am overjoyed that you think of continuing here. I am, ſtap my vitals. (To. Amanda.) For Gad's ſake, Madam, how has your ladyſhip been able to ſubſiſt thus long, under the fatigue of a country life?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: My life has been very far from that, my Lord, it has been a very quiet one.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Why that's the fatigue I ſpeak of, Madam; for 'tis impoſſible to be quiet, without thinking; now thinking is to me the greateſt fatigue in the world.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Does not your lordſhip love reading then?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Oh, paſſionately, Madam, but I never think of what I read.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Why, can your lordſhip read without thinking?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: O Lard, can your ladyſhip pray without devotion, Madam?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Well, I muſt own, I think books the beſt entertainment in the world.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: I am ſo much of your ladyſhip's mind, Madam, that I have a private gallery in town, where I walk ſometimes, which is furniſhed with nothing but books and looking glaſſes. Madam, I have gilded them, and ranged them ſo prettily, before Gad, it is the moſt entertaining thing in the world, to walk and look at them.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Nay, I love a neat library too, but 'tis, I think, the inſide of a book ſhould recommend it moſt to us.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p:
That, I muſt confeſs, I am not altogether ſo fand of, far to my mind, the inſide of a book is to entertain one's ſelf with the forced product of another man's brain. Now I think a man of quality and breeding may be much more diverted with the natural ſprauts of his own; but to ſay the truth, Madam, let a
man love reading never ſo well, when once he comes to know the tawn, he finds ſo many better ways of paſſing away the four-and-twenty hours, that it were ten thouſand pities he ſhould conſume his time in that. Far example, Madam, now my life, my life, Madam, is a perpetual ſtream of pleaſure, that glides through with ſuch a variety of entertainments, I believe the wiſeſt of our anceſtors never had the leaſt conception of any of 'em. I riſe, Madam, when in town, about twelve o'clock. I don't riſe ſooner, becauſe it is the worſt thing in the world for the complexion; nat that I pretend to be a beau, but a man muſt endeavour to look decent, leſt he makes ſo odious a figure in the ſide-bax, the ladies ſhould be compelled to turn their eyes upon the play; ſo, at twelve o'clock I ſay I riſe. Naw, if I find it a good day, I reſalve to take the exerciſe of riding, ſo drink my chocolate, and draw on my boots by two. On my return, I dreſs; and after dinner, lounge, perhaps to the Opera.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Your lordſhip, I ſuppoſe, is fond of muſic?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: O, paſſionately, on Tueſdays and Saturdays, provided there is good company, and one is not expected to undergo the fatigue of liſtening.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Does your lordſhip think that the caſe at the Opera?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p:
Moſt certainly, Madam; there is my Lady Tattle, my Lady Prate, my Lady Titter, my Lady Sneer, my Lady Giggle, and my Lady Grin,—theſe have boxes in the front, and while any favourite
air is ſinging, are the prettieſt company in the waurld, ſtap my vitals! May'nt we hope for the honour to ſee you added to our ſociety, Madam?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Alas, my Lord, I am the worſt company in the world at a concert, I'm ſo apt to attend to the muſic.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Why, Madam, that is very pardonable in the country, or at church; but a monſtrous inattention in a polite aſſembly. But I am afraid I tire the company?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Not at all; pray go on.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Why then, ladies, there only remains to add, that I generally conclude the evening at one or other of the Clubs, nat that I ever play deep; indeed I have been for ſome time tied up from loſing above five thouſand pawnds at a ſitting.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: But is'nt your Lordſhip ſometimes obliged to attend the weighty affairs of the nation?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Sir, as to weighty affairs, I leave them to weighty heads; I never intend mine ſhall be a burthen to my body.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Nay, my Lord, but you are a pillar of the ſtate.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: An ornamental pillar, Madam; for ſooner than undergo any part of the burthen, rat me, but the whole building ſhould fall to the ground.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: But, my Lord, a fine gentleman ſpends a great deal of his time in his intrigues; you have given us no account of them yet.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Soh! She would enquire into my amours, that's jealouſy; poor ſoul! I ſee ſhe's in love with me. (To her.) Why, Madam, I ſhould have mentioned my intrigues, but I am really afraid I begin to be troubleſome with the length of my viſit.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Your lordſhip is too entertaining to grow troubleſome any where.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: (Aſide.) That now was as much as if ſhe had ſaid pray make love to me. I'll let her ſee I'm quick of apprehenſion. (To her). O Lard, Madam, I had like to have forgot a ſecret I muſt needs tell your ladyſhip. (To Lov.) Ned, you muſt not be ſo jealous now as to liſten.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Not I, my Lord, I am too faſhionable a huſband to pry into the ſecrets of my wife.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: (To Aman. ſqueezing her hand) I am in love with you to deſperation, ſtrike me ſpeechleſs!

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: (Giving him a box o' the ear.) Then thus I return your paſſion,—an impudent fool!

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Gad's curſe, Madam, I'm a Peer of the Realm.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Hey, what the Devil do you affront my wife, Sir? Nay then— (Draws and fight.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Ah! What has my folly done?—Help! murder! help! Part them, for Heaven's ſake.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: (Falling back, and leaning on his ſword.) Ah! quite through the body, ſtap my vitals!

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: (Running to him.) I hope I han't killed the fool, however—bear him up—where's your wound?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Juſt thro' the guts.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Call a ſurgeon, there—unbutton him quickly.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Ay, pray make haſte.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: This miſchief you may thank yourſelf for.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: I may ſo, love's the Devil, indeed, Ned.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Here's Mr. Probe, ſir, was juſt going by the door.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: He's the welcomeſt man alive.

sp.speaker: PROBE.
sp.p: Stand by, ſtand by, ſtand by; pray, Gentlemen, ſtand by; Lord have mercy upon us! did you never ſee a man run through the body before? Pray ſtand by.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Ah! Mr. Probe, I'm a dead man.

sp.speaker: PROBE.
sp.p: A dead man, and I by! I ſhould laugh to ſee that, egad.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Prithee, don't ſtand prating, but look upon his wound.

sp.speaker: PROBE.
sp.p: Why, what if I won't look upon his wound this hour, ſir?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Why then he'll bleed to death, ſir.

sp.speaker: PROBE.
sp.p: Why then I'll fetch him to life again, ſir.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: 'Slife! he's run thro' the guts, I tell thee.

sp.speaker: PROBE.
sp.p: I wiſh he was run thro' the heart, and I ſhould get the more credit by his cure.—Now I hope you are ſatisfied?—Come, now let me come at him—now let me come at him— (viewing his wound) Oons! what a gaſh is here!—Why, ſir, a man may drive a coach and ſix horſes into your body!

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: PROBE.
sp.p: Why, what the devil have you run the gentleman thro' with a ſcythe?— (aſide) A little ſcratch between the ſkin and the ribs, that's all.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Let me ſee his wound.

sp.speaker: PROBE.
sp.p: Then you ſhall dreſs it, Sir—for if any body looks upon it I won't.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Why thou art the verieſt coxcomb I ever ſaw.

sp.speaker: PROBE.
sp.p: Sir, I am not maſter of my trade for nothing.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Surgeon!

sp.speaker: PROBE.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Are there any hopes?

sp.speaker: PROBE.
sp.p: Hopes! I can't tell—What are you willing to give for a cure?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Five hundred paunds with pleaſure.

sp.speaker: PROBE.
sp.p: Why then perhaps there may be hopes; but we muſt avoid a further delay—here—help the gentleman into a chair, and carry him to my houſe preſently—that's the propereſt place— (aſide) to bubble him out of his money.—Come, a chair—a chair quickly—there, in with him.— (they put him into a chair)

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Dear Loveleſs, adieu: if I die, I forgive thee; and if I live, I hope thou wilt do as much by me.—I am ſorry you and I ſhould quarrel, but I hope here's an end on't; for if you are ſatisfied, I am.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: I ſhall hardly think it worth my proſecuting any farther, ſo you may be at reſt, ſir.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Thou art a generous fellow, ſtrike me dumb!— (aſide) but thou haſt an impertinent wife, ſtap my vitals!

sp.speaker: PROBE.
sp.p: So—carry him off—carry him off—we ſhall have him prate himſelf into a fever by and by—carry him off▪ [Exit. with Ld. Foppington and Probe.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Now on my knees, my dear, let me aſk your pardon for my indiſcretion—my own I never ſhall obtain.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Oh, there's no harm done—you ſerv'd him well.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: He did indeed deſerve it; but I tremble to think how dear my indiſcreet reſentment might have coſt you.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: O, no matter—never trouble yourſelf about that.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: So, ſo, I'm glad to find you all alive—I met a wounded Peer carrying off—for Heav'ns ſake what was the matter?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: O, a trifle—he would have made love to my wife before my face, ſo ſhe obliged him with a box o'the ear, and I run him through the body, that was all.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Bagatelle on all ſides—but pray, Madam, how long has this noble Lord been an humble ſervant of your's?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: This is the firſt I have heard on't—ſo I ſuppoſe 'tis his quality more than his love has brought him into this adventure. He thinks his title an authentic paſſport to every woman's heart, below the degree of a Peereſs.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: He's coxcomb enough to think any thing; but I would not have you brought into trouble for him.—I hope there's no danger of his life?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: None at all—he's fallen into the hands of a roguiſh ſurgeon, who, I perceive, deſigns to frighten a little money out of him—but I ſaw his wound—'tis nothing—he may go to the ball tonight if he pleaſes.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: I am glad you have corrected him without farther miſchief, or you might have deprived me of the pleaſure of executing a plot againſt his Lordſhip, which I have been contriving with an old acquaintance of yours.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Explain—

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: His brother, Tom Faſhion, is come down here, and we have it in contemplation to ſave him the trouble of his intended wedding; but we want your aſſiſtance. Tom would have called, but he is preparing for his enterprize, ſo I promiſed to bring you to him—ſo, ſir, if theſe ladies can ſpare you—

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p:
I'll go with you with all my heart— (aſide) —tho' I could wiſh, methinks, to ſtay and gaze a little
longer on that creature—Good Gods! how engaging ſhe is—but what have I to do with beauty?—I have already had my portion, and muſt not covet more.— (To Townly) Come, ſir, when you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Ladies, your ſervant.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Mr. Loveleſs, pray one word with you before you go.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: (to Townly.) I'll overtake you, Colonel. (Exit Townly). What would my dear?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Only a woman's fooliſh queſtion, how do you like my couſin here?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Jealous already, Amanda?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Not at all—I aſk you for another reaſon.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Whate'er her reaſon be, I muſt not tell her true. (to her). Why, I confeſs ſhe's handſome—but you muſt not think I ſlight your kinſwoman, if I own to you, of all the women who may claim that character, ſhe is the laſt would triumph in my heart.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: I'm ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Now tell me why you aſk'd?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: At night I will—Adieu.—

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: (Kiſſing her. I'm your's— (Exit.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: (Aſide.) I'm glad to find he does not like her, for I have a great mind to perſuade her to come and live with me.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Soh! I find my Colonel continues in his airs; there muſt be ſomething more at the bottom of this than the provocation he pretends from me.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: For Heav'ns ſake, Berinthia, tell me what way I ſhall take to perſuade you to come and live with me?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Why one way in the world there is—and but one.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: And pray what is that?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA:
sp.p: It is to aſſure me—I ſhall be very welcome.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: If that be all, you ſhall e'en ſleep here tonight.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: To-night!

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Yes, to-night.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Why the people where I lodge will think me mad.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Let 'em think what they pleaſe.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p:
Say you ſo, Amanda?—Why then they ſhall think what they pleaſe—for I'm a young widow, and I care not what any body thinks.—Ah,
Amanda, it's a delicious thing to be a young widow.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: You'll hardly make me think ſo.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Puh! becauſe you are in love with your huſband—but that is not every woman's caſe.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: I hope 'twas your's at leaſt.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Mine, ſay you?—Now I have a great mind to tell you a lye, but I ſhall do it ſo aukwardly, you'd find me out.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Then e'en ſpeak the truth.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Shall I?—then, after all, I did love him, Amanda, as a Nun does penance.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: How did you live together?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Like man and wife—aſunder—he lov'd the country—I the town.—He hawks and hounds—I coaches and equipage.—He eating and drinking—I carding and playing.—He the ſound of a horn—I the ſqueek of a fiddle.—We were dull company at table—worſe a-bed: whenever we met we gave one another the ſpleen, and never agreed but once, which was about lying alone.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: But tell me one thing truly and ſincerely—notwithſtanding all theſe jars, did not his death at laſt extremely trouble you?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: O yes.—I was forced to wear an odious Widows' band a twelve-month for't.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Women, I find, have different inclinations:—prithee, Berinthia, inſtruct me a little farther—for I'm ſo great a novice, I'm almoſt aſham'd on't.—Not Heav'n knows that what you call intrigues have any charms for me—the practical part of all unlawful love is—

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: O 'tis abominable—but for the ſpeculative, that we muſt all confeſs is entertaining enough.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Pray, be ſo juſt then to me, to believe, 'tis with a world of innocence I would enquire whether you think thoſe, we call Women of Reputation, do really eſcape all other men, as they do thoſe ſhadows of beaus?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: O no, Amanda—there are a ſort of men make dreadful work amongſt 'em—men that may be called the Beaus Antipathy—for they agree in nothing but walking upon two legs. Theſe have brains—the beau has none.—Theſe are in love with their miſtreſs—the beau with himſelf.—They take care of their reputation—he's induſtrious to deſtroy it—They are decent—he's a fop. They are men—he's an aſs.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: If this be their character, I fancy we had here e'en now a pattern of 'em both.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: His Lordſhip and Colonel Townly?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: The ſame.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: As for the Lord, he's eminently ſo; and for the other, I can aſſure you there's not a man in town who has a better intereſt with the women, that are worth having an intereſt with.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: He anſwers then the opinion I had ever of him—Heav'ns! what a difference there is between a man like him, and that vain nauſeous fop, Lord Foppington— (taking her hand) I muſt acquaint you with a ſecret, couſin—'tis not that fool alone has talked to me of love.—Townly has been tampering too.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: (Aſide) So, ſo!—here the myſtery comes out!—Colonel Townly!—impoſſible, my dear!

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: 'Tis true, indeed!—tho' he has done it in vain; nor do I think that all the merit of mankind combined, could ſhake the tender love I bear my huſband; yet I will own to you, Berinthia, I did not ſtart at his addreſſes, as when they came from one whom I contemned.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: (Aſide.) O this is better and better—well ſaid innocence!—and you really think, my dear, that nothing could abate your conſtancy and attachment to your huſband?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Nothing, I am convinced.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: What if you found he lov'd another woman better?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Well!—why were I that thing they call a ſlighted wife; ſomebody ſhould run the riſk of being that thing they call—a huſband.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: O fie, Berinthia, no revenge ſhould ever be taken againſt a huſband—but to wrong his bed is a vengeance, which of all vengeance—

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Is the ſweeteſt!—ha! ha! ha I—don't I talk madly?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Madly indeed!

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Yet I'm very innocent.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: That I dare ſwear you are.—I know how to make allowances for your humour—but you reſolve then never to marry again?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: O no!—I reſolve I will.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: That I never may.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: You banter me.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Indeed I don't—but I conſider I'm a woman, and form my reſolutions accordingly.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Well, my opinion is, form what reſolution you will, matrimony will be the end on't.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: I doubt it—but A Heav'ns!—I have buſineſs at home, and am half an hour too late.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: As you are to return with me, I'll juſt give ſome orders, and walk with you.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Well, make haſte, and we'll finiſh this ſubject as we go. [Exit Amanda.

Ah! poor Amanda, you have led a country life! Well, this diſcovery is lucky!—baſe Townly!—at once falſe to me, and treacherous to his friend! and my innocent, demure, couſin, too!—I have it in my power to be revenged on her, however. Her huſband, if I have any ſkill in countenance, would be as happy in my ſmiles, as Townly can hope to be in her's.—I'll make the experiment, come what will on't.—The woman who can forgive the being robb'd of a favour'd lover, muſt be either an ideot or a wanton.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter LORD FOPPINGTON and LA VAROLE.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: HEY, fellow—let my vis-a-vis come to the door.

sp.speaker: LA VAROLE.
sp.p: Will your lordſhip venture ſo ſoon to expoſe yourſelf to the weather?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Sir, I will venture as ſoon as I can to expoſe myſelf to the ladies.

sp.speaker: LA VAROLE.
sp.p: I wiſh your lordſhip would pleaſe to keep houſe a little longer; I'm affraid your honour does not well conſider your wound.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: My wound!—I would not be in eclipſe another day, tho' I had as many wounds in my body as I have had in my heart. So mind, Varole, let theſe cards be left as directed. For this evening I ſhall wait on my father-in-law, Sir Tunbelly, and I mean to commence my devoirs to the lady, by giving an entertainment at her father's expence; and heark thee, tell Mr. Loveleſs I requeſt he and his company will honour me with their preſence, or I ſhall think we are not friends.

sp.speaker: LA VAROLE.
sp.p: I will be ſure. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Brother, your ſervant, how do you find yourſelf to day?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: So well, that I have ardered my coach to the door;—ſo there's no danger of death this baut, Tam.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: I'm very glad of it.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON,
sp.p: (Aſide.) That I believe's a lye.—Prithee, Tam, tell me one thing—did not your heart cut a caper up to your mauth, when you heard I was ran thro' the bady?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Why do you think it ſhould?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Becauſe I remember mine did ſo when I heard my uncle was ſhot thro' the head.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: It then did very ill.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Prithee, why ſo?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Becauſe he uſed you very well.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Well!—Naw, ſtrike me dumb, he ſtarv'd me—he has let me want a thauſand women, for want of a thauſand pound.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Then he hinder'd you from making a great many ill bargains—for I think no woman worth money that will take money.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: If I was a younger brother, I ſhould think ſo too.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Then you are ſeldom much in love?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Never, ſtap my vitals.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Why then did you make all this buſtle about Amanda?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Becauſe ſhe was a woman of an inſolent virtue—and I thought myſelf piqu'd in honour to debauch her.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Very well. Here's a rare fellow for you, to • ave the ſpending of five thouſand pounds a year. But now for my buſineſs with him.—Brother, tho' I know to talk of buſineſs (eſpecially of money) is a theme not quite ſo entertaining to you as that of the ladies, my neceſſities are ſuch, I hope you'll have patience to hear me.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: The greatneſs of your neceſſities, Tam, is the worſt argument in the warld for your being patiently heard. I do believe you are going to make a very good ſpeech, but ſtrike me dumb, it has the worſt beginning of any ſpeech I have heard this twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: I'm ſorry you think ſo.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: I do believe thou art—but come, let's know the affair quickly.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Why then, my caſe in a word is this.—The neceſſary expences of my travels have ſo much exceeded the wretched income of my annuity, that I have been forced to mortgage it for five hundred pounds, which is ſpent. So unleſs you are ſo kind as to aſſiſt me in redeeming it, I know no remedy but to take a purſe.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Why, faith, Tam, to give you my ſenſe of the thing, I do think taking a purſe the beſt remedy in the warld—for if you ſucceed you are relieved that way, if you are taken—you are relieved t'other.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: I'm glad to ſee you are in ſo pleaſant a humour; I hope I ſhall find the effects on't.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Why, do you then really think it a reaſonable thing that I ſhould give you five hundred pawnds?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: I do not aſk it as a due, brother, I am willing to receive it as a favour.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p:
Then thou art willing to receive it any how, ſtrike me ſpeechleſs.—But theſe are d—n'd times to give money in; taxes are ſo great, repairs ſo exorbitant, tenants ſuch rogues, and bouquets ſo dear, that the Devil take me, I am reduced to to that extremity in my caſh, I have been forced to retrench in that one article of ſweet pawder,
till I have brought it dawn to five guineas a maunth—now judge, Tam, whether I can ſpare you five hundred pawnds?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: If you can't I muſt ſtarve, that's all. (Aſide.) Damn him.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: All I can ſay is, you ſhould have been a better huſband.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Ouns!—If you can't live upon ten thouſand a year, how do you think I ſhould do't upon two hundred?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Don't be in a paſſion, Tam, for paſſion is the moſt unbecoming thing in the warld—to the face. Look you, I don't love to ſay any thing to you to make you melancholy, but upon this occaſion I muſt take leave to put you in mind, that a running-horſe does require more attendance than a coach-horſe.—Nature has made ſome difference 'twixt you and me.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Yes.—She has made you older. (Aſide.) Plague take her.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: That is not all, Tam.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Why, what is there elſe?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: (Looking firſt upon himſelf and then upon his brother.) Aſk the ladies.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p:
Why, thou Eſſence-bottle, thou Muſk Cat,—doſt
thou then think thou haſt any advantage over me but what fortune has given thee?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: I do, ſtap my vitals.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Now, by all that's great and powerful thou art the Prince of Coxcombs.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Sir, I am proud at being at the head of ſo prevailing a party.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Will nothing then provoke thee?—Draw, Coward.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Look you, Tam, you know I have always taken you for a mighty dull fellow, and here is one of the fooliſheſt plats broke out, that I have ſeen a lang time. Your poverty makes life ſo burthen-ſome to you, you would provoke me to a quarrel, in hopes either to ſlip through my lungs into my eſtate, or to get yourſelf run thro' the guts, to put an end to your pain, but I will diſappoint you in both your deſigns; far with the temper of a Philaſapher, and the diſcretion of a ſtateſman—I ſhall leave the room with my ſword in the ſcabbard. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: So! farewell brother; and now conſcience I defy thee.—Lory!

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Here's rare news, Lory, his Lordſhip has given me a pill has purged off all my ſcruples.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Then my heart's at eaſe again. For I have been in a lamentable fright, ſir, ever ſince your conſcience had the impudence to intrude into your company.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Be at peace; it will come there no more, my brother has given it a wring by the noſe, and I have kick'd it down ſtairs. So run away to the inn, get the chaiſe ready quickly, and bring it to dame Coupler's without a moment's delay.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Then, ſir, you are going ſtriaght about the fortune?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: I am.—Away—fly, Lory.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: The happieſt day I ever ſaw. I'm upon the wing already.

div.head: SCENE, A GARDEN.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Is my wife within?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: No, ſir, ſhe has been gone out this half hour.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p:
Well, leave me. (Exit Servant.) How ſtrangely does my mind run on this widow—never
was my heart ſo ſuddenly ſeiz'd on before—that my wife ſhould pick out her, of all woman-kind, to be her playfellow.—But what fate does, let fate anſwer for—I ſought it not—ſoh!—by heav'ns!—here ſhe comes.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: What makes you look ſo thoughtful, Sir? I hope you are not ill.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: I was debating, madam, whether I was ſo or not, and that was it which made me look ſo thoughtful.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Is it then ſo hard a matter to decide?—I thought all people were acquainted with their own bodies, tho' few people know their own minds.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: What if the diſtemper I ſuſpect be in the mind?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Why then I'll undertake to preſcribe you a cure.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Alas! you undertake you know not what.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: So far at leaſt then you allow me to be a Phyſician.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Nay, I'll allow you to be ſo yet farther, for I have reaſon to believe, ſhould I put myſelf into your hands, you would increaſe my diſtemper.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Oh, you might betray my complaints to my wife.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: And ſo loſe all my practice.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Will you then keep my ſecret?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: I'm ſatisfied. Now hear my ſymptoms, and give me your advice. The firſt were theſe when I ſaw you at the play; a random glance you threw, at firſt alarm'd me. I could not turn my eyes from whence the danger came—I gaz'd upon you till my heart began to pant—nay, even now on your approaching me, my illneſs is ſo increas'd, that if you do not help me I ſhall, whilſt you look on, conſume to Aſhes. (Taking her hand.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: (Breaking from him.) O Lord let me go, 'tis the plague, and we ſhall be infected.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Then we'll die together, my charming angel.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: O Gad! the devil's in you. Lord, let me go—here's ſomebody coming.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Sir, my lady's come home, and deſires to ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Tell her I'm coming. (Exit Servant).—(To Berinthia) But before I go, one glaſs of nectar to drink her health.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Stand off, or I ſhall hate you, by heavens.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: (Kiſſing her.) In matters of love, a woman's oath is no more to be minded than a man's. (Exit Lov.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Um!

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Soh! what's here—Berinthia and Loveleſs—and in ſuch cloſe converſation!—I cannot now wonder at her indifference in excuſing herſelf to me!—O rare woman,—well then, let Loveleſs look to his wife, 'twill be but the retort courteous on both ſides.— (To Berinthia.) Your ſervant, Madam, I need not aſk you how you do, you have got ſo good a colour.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: No better than I uſed to have, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: A little more blood in your cheeks.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: I have been walking!

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Is that all? Pray was it Mr. Loveleſs went from here juſt now?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: O yes—he has been walking with me.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: He has!

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Upon my word I think he is a very agreeable man!—and there is certainly ſomething particularly inſinuating in his addreſs!

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: So! ſo! ſhe has n't even the modeſty to diſſemble! Pray, madam, may I, without impertinence, trouble you with a few ſerious queſtions?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: As many as you pleaſe; but pray let them be as little ſerious as poſſible.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Is it not near two years ſince I have preſumed to addreſs you?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: I don't know exactly—but it has been a tedious long time.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Have I not, during that period, had every reaſon to believe that my aſſiduities were far from being unacceptable?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Why, to do you juſtice, you have been extremely troubleſome—and I confeſs I have been more civil to you than you deſerved.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Did I not come to this place at your expreſs deſire? and for no purpoſe but the honour of meeting you?—and after waſting a month in diſappointment, have you condeſcended to explain, or in the ſlighteſt way apologize, for your conduct?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: O heav'ns! apologize for my conduct!—apologiſe to you!—O you barbarian!—But pray now, my good ſerious Colonel, have you any thing more to add?

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Nothing, madam, but that after ſuch behaviour I am leſs ſurpris'd at what I ſaw juſt now; it is not very wonderful that the woman who can trifle with the delicate addreſſes of an honourable lover, ſhould be found coquetting with the huſband of her friend.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Very true—no more wonderful than it was for this honourable lover to divert himſelf in the abſence of this coquet, with endeavouring to ſeduce his friend's wife! O Colonel, Colonel, don't talk of honor or your friend, for heav'ns ſake.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: S'death! how came ſhe to ſuſpect this.—Really madam, I don't underſtand you.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Nay—nay—you ſaw I did not pretend to miſunderſtand you.—But here comes the Lady—perhaps you would be glad to be left with her for an explanation.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: O madam, this recrimination is a poor reſource, and to convince you how much you are miſtaken, I beg leave to decline the happineſs you propoſe me.—Madam, your ſervant.

div.stage: Enter AMANDA. (TOWNLY whiſpers AMANDA, and exit.)

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: He carries it off well however—upon my word—very well!—how tenderly they part!—So, couſin—I hope you have not been chiding your admirer for being with me—I aſſure you we have been talking of you.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Fie, Berinthia!—my admirer—will you never learn to talk in earneſt of any thing?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Why this ſhall be in earneſt, if you pleaſe; for my part I only tell you matter of fact.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: I'm ſure there's ſo much jeſt and earneſt in what you ſay to me on this ſubject, I ſcarce know how to take it.—I have juſt parted with Mr. Loveleſs—perhaps it is my fancy, but I think there is an alteration in his manner, which alarms me.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: And ſo you are jealous? is that all?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: That all!—is jealouſy then nothing?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: It ſhould be nothing, if I were in your caſe.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Why what would you do?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: I'd cure myſelf.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p:
Care as little for my huſband as he did for me.
Look you, Amanda, you may build caſtles in the air, and fume, and fret, and grow thin, and lean, and pale, and ugly, if you pleaſe, but I tell you, no man worth having is true to his wife, or ever was, or ever will be ſo.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Do you then really think he's falſe to me? for I did not ſuſpect him.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Think ſo!—I am ſure of it.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: You are ſure on't?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Poſitively—he fell in love at the play.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Right—the very ſame—but who could have told you this?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Um—O—Townly!—I ſuppoſe your huſband has made him his confidant.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: O baſe Loveleſs!—and what did Townly ſay on't?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: So, ſo—why ſhould ſhe aſk that?— (aſide)—ſay!—why he abuſed Loveleſs extremely, and ſaid all the tender things of you in the world.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Did he?—Oh! my heart!—I'm very ill—I muſt go to the chamber—dear Berinthia, don't leave me a moment. (Exit.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p:
No—don't fear.—So—there is certainly ſome affection on her ſide at leaſt, towards Townly.
If it prove ſo, and her agreeable huſband perſeveres—Heav'n ſend me reſolution!—well—how this buſineſs will end I know not—but I ſeem to be in as fair a way to loſe my gallant Colonel, as a boy is to be a rogue, when he's put clerk to an attorney. [Exit.

div.head: SCENE, a Country Houſe.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: So—here's our inheritance, Lory, if we can but get into poſſeſſion—but methinks the ſeat of our family looks like Noah's ark, as if the chief part on't were deſigned for the fowls of the air, and the beaſts of the field.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, don't let your head run upon the orders of building here—get but the heireſs, let the devil take the houſe.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Get but the houſe! let the devil take the heireſs, I ſay—but come, we have no time to ſquander, knock at the door— [Lory knocks two or three times.
What the devil have they got no ears in this houſe?—knock harder.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: I'gad, ſir, this will prove ſome inchanted caſtle—we ſhall have the giant come out by and by with his club, and beat our brains out. (knocks again.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Huſh—they come— (from within) who is there?

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Open the door and ſee—is that your country breeding?—

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: (within) Ay, but two words to that bargain—Tummas, is the blunderbuſs prim'd?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Ouns! give 'em good words Lory—or we ſhall be ſhot here a fortune catching.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Egad ſir, I think you're in the right on't—ho!—Mr. what d'ye callum—will you pleaſe to let us in? or are we to be left to grow like willows by your moat ſide? (Servant appears at the window with a blunderbuſs)

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Weel naw, what's ya're buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Nothing, ſir, but to wait upon Sir Tunbelly, with your leave.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: To weat upon Sir Tunbelly?—why you'll find that's juſt as Sir Tunbelly pleaſes.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: But will you do me the favour, ſir, to know whether Sir Tunbelly pleaſes or not?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Why look you d'ye ſee, with good words much may be done.—Ralph, go thy waes, and aſk Sir Tunbelly if he pleaſes to be waited upon—and doſt hear? call to nurſe that ſhe may lock up Miſs Hoyden before the geats open.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: D'ye hear that Lory?

div.stage: Enter SIR TUNBELLY, with Servants, armed with guns, clubs, pitchforks, &c.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: O (Running behind his maſter) O Lord, O Lord, Lord, we are both dead men.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Take heed fool, thy fear will ruin us.

sp.speaker: IORY.
sp.p: My fear, ſir, 'ſdeath, ſir, I fear nothing— (aſide) would I were well up to the chin in a horſe pond.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Who is it here has any buſineſs with me?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Sir, 'tis I, if your name be Sir Tunbelly Clumſey?

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Sir, my name is Sir Tunbelly Clumſy, whether you have any buſineſs with me or not—ſo you ſee I am not aſham'd of my name, nor my face either.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Sir, you have no cauſe that I know of.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Sir, if you have no cauſe either, I deſire to know who you are; for 'till I know your name, I ſhan't aſk you to come into my houſe: and when I do know your name, 'tis ſix to four I don't aſk you then.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: (Giving him a Letter) Sir, I hope you'll find this letter an authentic paſſport.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p:
Cod's my life, from Mrs. Coupler.—I aſk your Lordſhip's pardon ten thouſand times— (to his Servant) —Here, run in a doors quickly; get a Scotch
coal fire in the great parlour—ſet all the Turkey work chairs in their places; get the braſs candleſticks out, and be ſure ſtick the ſocket full of laurel, run— (turning to Young Faſhion) My Lord, I aſk your Lordſhip's pardon— (to Servant) and do you hear, run away to nurſe, bid her let Miſs Hoyden looſe again. [Exit Servant.

(To Young Faſhion) I hope your honour will excuſe the diſorder of my family—we are not uſed to receive men of your Lordſhip's great quality every day—pray where are your coaches and ſervants, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Sir, that I might give you and your daughter a proof how impatient I am to be nearer akin to you, I left my equipage to follow me, and came away poſt with only one ſervant.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip does me too much honour—It was expoſing your perſon to too much fatigue and danger, I proteſt it was—but my daughter ſhall endeavour to make you what amends ſhe can—and tho' I ſay it, that ſhould not ſay it, Hoyden has charms.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Sir, I am not a ſtranger to them, tho' I am to her: common fame has done her juſtice.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: My Lord, I am common Fame's very grateful humble ſervant.—My Lord, my girl's young—Hoyden is young, my Lord; but this I muſt ſay for her, what ſhe wants in art, ſhe has by nature—what ſhe wants in experience, ſhe has in breeding—and what's wanting in her age, is made good in her conſtitution—ſo pray, my Lord, walk in; pray, my Lord, walk in.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Sir, I wait upon you. [Ex. thro' the gate.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Sure, nobody was ever uſed as I am. I know well enough what other girls do, for all they think to make a fool of me. It's well I have a huſband •… coming, or I'cod I'd marry the baker, I would ſo.—Nobody can knock at the gate, but preſently I muſt be lock'd up—and here's the young greyhound can run looſe about the houſe all the day long, ſo ſhe can.—'Tis very well—

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Miſs Hoyden, Miſs, Miſs, Miſs, Miſs Hoyden!

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Well, what do you make ſuch a noiſe for, ha?—what do you din a body's ears for?—can't one be at quiet for you?

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: What do I din your ears for?—here's one come will din your ears for you.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: What care I who's come?—I care not a fig who comes, nor who goes, as long as I muſt be lock'd up like the ale cellar.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: That, Miſs, is for fear you ſhould be drank before you are ripe.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: O don't you trouble your head about that, I'm as ripe as you, though not ſo mellow.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Very well—now I have a good mind to lock you up again, and not let you ſee my Lord to-night.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: My Lord! why is my huſband come?

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Yes, marry is he, and a goodly perſon too.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: (Hugging Nurſe) O my dear nurſe, forgive me this once, and I'll never miſuſe you again; no, if I do, you ſhall give me three thumps on the back, and a great pinch by the cheek.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Ah! the poor thing, ſee how it melts, its as full of good nature as an egg's full of meat.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: But my dear Nurſe, don't lie now, is he come by your troth?

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Yes, by my truly is he.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: O Lord! I'll go and put on my laced tucker, tho' I'm lock'd up a month for't. [Exit running.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: WELL, Miſs, how do you like your huſband that is to be?

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: O Lord, Nurſe, I'm ſo overjoy'd, I can ſcarce contain myſelf.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: O but you muſt have a care of being too fond, for men now-a-days, hate a woman that loves 'em.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Love him! Why do you think I love him, Nurſe? I'cod, I would not ca • e if he was hang'd, ſo I were but once married to him.—No, that which pleaſes me, is to think what work I'll make when I get to London; for when I am a wife and a Lady both, I'cod I'll flaunt it with the beſt of 'em. Aye, and I ſhall have money enough to do ſo too, Nurſe.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p:
Ah! there's no knowing that Miſs, for though theſe Lords have a power of wealth, indeed, yet, as I have heard ſay, they give it all to their ſluts and their trulls, who joggle it about in their
coaches, with a murrain to 'em, whilſt poor Madam ſits ſighing and wiſhing, and has not a ſpare half crown to buy her a Practice of Piety.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: O, but for that, don't deceive yourſelf, Nurſe, for this I muſt ſay of my Lord, he's as free as an open houſe at Chriſtmas. For this very morning he told me, I ſhould have ſix hundred a year to buy pins. Now, Nurſe, if he gives me ſix hundred a year to buy pins, what do you think he'll give me to buy fine petticoats?

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Ah, my deareſt, he deceives thee fouly, and he's no better than a rogue for his pains. Theſe Londoners have got a gibberage with 'em, would confound a gipſey. That which they call pinmoney, is to buy their wives every thing in the verſal world, down to their very ſhoe-knots.—Nay, I have heard folks ſay, that ſome ladies, if they will have gallants, as they call 'em, are forced to find them out of their pin-money too. But, look, look, if his Honor be not coming to you.—Now, if I were ſure you would behave yourſelf handſomely, and not diſgrace me that have brought you up, I'd leave you alone together.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: That's my beſt Nurſe, do as you'd be done by—truſt us together this once, and if I don't ſhew my breeding, may I never be married but die an old maid.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Well, this once I'll venture you.—But if you diſparage me—

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Never fear. [Exit Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Your ſervant, Madam, I'm glad to find you alone, for I have ſomething of importance to ſpeak to you about.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Sir, (my Lord, I meant) you may ſpeak to me about what you pleaſe, I ſhall give you a civil anſwer.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: You give me ſo obliging a one, it encourages me to tell you in a few words, what I think both for your intereſt and mine. Your father, I ſuppoſe you know, has reſolved to make me happy in being your huſband, and I hope I may depend on your conſent to perform what he deſires.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Sir, I never diſobey my father in any thing but eating green gooſeberries.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: So good a daughter muſt needs be an admirable wife.—I am therefore impatient till you are mine, and hope you will ſo far conſider the violence of my love, that you won't have the cruelty to defer my happineſs ſo long as your father deſigns it.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, how long is that?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Madam—a thouſand years—a whole week.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: A week!—Why I ſhall be an old woman by that time.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: And I an old man.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Why I thought it was to be to-morrow morning, as ſoon as I was up. I'm ſure nurſe told me ſo.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: And it ſhall be to-morrow morning, if you'll conſent?

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: If I'll conſent! Why I thought I was to obey you as my huſband?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: That's when we are married. Till then I'm to obey you.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Why then if we are to take it by turns, it's the ſame thing. I'll obey you now, and when we are married you ſhall obey me.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: With all my heart. But I doubt we muſt get Nurſe on our ſide, or we ſhall hardly prevail with the Chaplain.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: No more we ſhan't indeed, for he loves her better than he loves his pulpit, and would always be a-preaching to her by his good will.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Why then, my dear, if you'll call her hither, we'll try to perſuade her preſently.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: O Lord, I can tell you a way how to perſwade her to any thing.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Why tell her ſhe's a handſome, comely woman, and give her half-a-crown.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Nay, if that will do, ſhe ſhall have half a ſcore of them.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: O Gemini, for half that ſhe'd marry you herſelf.—I'll run and call her. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Soh, matters go ſwimmingly. This is a rare girl I'faith. I ſhall have a fine time on't with her at London. But no matter—ſhe brings me an eſtate will afford me a ſeparate maintenance.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: So, Lory, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: Here, Sir; an intercepted packet from the enemy—your brother's poſtillion brought it—I knew the livery; pretended to be a ſervant of Sir Tunbelly's, and ſo got poſſeſſion of the letter.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p:
(Looking at it) Ouns!—He tells Sir Tunbelly here, that he will be with him this evening, with a large party
to ſupper,—'egad! I muſt marry the girl directly.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: O Zounds, Sir, directly to be ſure! Here ſhe comes. [Exit Lory.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: And the old Jeſabel with her. She has a thorough procuring countenance, however.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: How do you do, Mrs. Nurſe?—I deſired your young lady would give me leave to ſee you, that I might thank you for your extraordinary care and conduct in her education; pray accept of this ſmall acknowledgement for it at preſent, and depend upon my farther kindneſs when I ſhall be that happy thing her husband.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
