sp.p: (Aſide.) Gold by Maakins!—Your Honour's goodneſs is too great. Alas! all I can boaſt of is, I gave her pure good milk, and ſo your Honour would have ſaid, an you had ſeen how-the poor thing thrived—and how it would look up in my face—and crow and laugh it would!

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p:
(To Nurſe, taking her angrily aſide.) Pray one word with you. Prithee, Nurſe, don't ſtand ripping up old ſtories, to make one aſhamed before one's love; do you think ſuch a fine, proper gentleman as he is, cares for a fiddle-come tale of a child? If you have a mind to make him have a good opinion of a woman, don't tell him what one did then, tell him what one can do now. (To him.) I hope your Honour will
excuſe my miſ-manners, to whiſper before you, it was only to give ſome orders about the family.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: O every thing, Madam, is to give way to buſineſs; beſides, good houſewiſery is a very commendable quality in a young lady.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Pary, Sir, are young ladies good houſewives at London town? Do they darn their own linnen.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: O no;—they ſtudy how to ſpend money, not to ſave.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: I'cod, I don't know but that may be better ſport, ha, Nurſe!

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Well, you ſhall have your choice when you come there.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Shall I?—then by my troth I'll get there as faſt as I can. (To Nurſe.) His Honour deſires you'll be ſo kind, as to let us be married to-morrow.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: To-morrow, my dear Madam?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Aye faith, Nurſe, you may well be ſurpriſed at Miſs's wanting to put it off ſo long—to-morrow! no, no,—'tis now, this very hour, I would have the ceremony perform'd.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: I'cod with all my heart.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: O mercy, worſe and worſe.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Yes, ſweet Nurſe, now, and privately. For all things being ſigned and ſealed, why ſhould Sir Tunbelly make us ſtay a week for a wedding dinner?

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: But if you ſhould be married now, what will you do when Sir Tunbelly calls for you to be wedded?

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Why then we will be married again.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: What twice, my child!

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: I'cod, I don't care how often I'm married, not I.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Well—I'm ſuch a tender hearted fool, I find I can refuſe you nothing. So you ſhall e'en follow your own inventions.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Shall I?— (Aſide.) O Lord I could leap over the Moon.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Dear Nurſe, this goodneſs of your's ſhan't go unrewarded. But now you muſt employ your power with the Chaplain, that he may do his friendly office too, and then we ſhall be all happy. Do you think you can prevail with him?

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Prevail with him!—Or he ſhall never prevail with me, I can tell him that.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p:
I'm glad to hear it; however, to ſtrengthen
your intereſt with him, you may let him know, I have ſeveral fat livings in my gift, and that the firſt that ſalls ſhall be in your diſpoſal.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Nay then, I'll make him marry more folks than one, I'll promiſe him.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Faith do, Nurſe, make him marry you too, I'm ſure he'll do't for a fat living.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Well, Nurſe, while you go and ſettle matters with him, your lady and I will go and take a walk in the garden. [Exit Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: (Giving her his hand.) Come, Madam, dare you venture yourſelf alone with me?

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: O dear, yes, Sir, I don't think you'll do any thing to me I need be afraid on. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.p: If you pleaſe, Madam, only to ſay whether you'll have me buy them or not?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Yes—no—go—Teazer!—I care not what you do—prithee leave me. [Exit Maid.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: What, in the name of Jove's the matter with you?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: The matter, Berinthia? I'm almoſt mad; I'm plagued to death.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Who is it that plagues you?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Who do you think ſhould plague a wife, but her husband?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: O ho! is it come to that?—we ſhall have you wiſh yourſelf a widow, by and bye.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Would I were any thing but what I am!—a baſe, ungrateful man, to uſe me thus!

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: What, has he given you freſh reaſon to ſuſpect his wandering?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Every hour gives me reaſon.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: And yet, Amanda, you perhaps at this moment cauſe in another's breaſt the ſame tormenting doubts and jealouſies which you feel ſo ſenſibly yourſelf.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Heaven knows I would not!

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p:
Why, you can't tell but there may be ſome one as tenderly attached to Townly, whom you
boaſt of as your conqueſt, as you can be to your husband.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: I'm ſure I never encouraged his pretenſions.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Pſhaw! Pſhaw!—No ſenſible man ever perſeveres to love, without encouragement. Why have you not treated him as you have Lord Foppington?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Becauſe he has not preſum'd ſo far. But let us drop the ſubject. Men, not women, are riddles. Mr. Loveleſs now follows ſome flirt for variety, whom I'm ſure he does not like ſo well as he does me.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: That's more than you know, Madam.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Why, do you know the ugly thing?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: I think I can gueſs at the perſon—but ſhe's no ſuch ugly thing neither.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Is ſhe very handſome?

sp.speaker: BERINNHIA.
sp.p: Truly I think ſo.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Whate'er ſhe be, I'm ſure he does not like her well enough to beſtow any thing more than a little outward gallantry upon her.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p:
(Aſide.) Outward gallantry.—I can't bear this.—Come, come, don't you be too ſecure, Amanda; while you ſuffer Townly to imagine that you do not deteſt him for his deſigns on you, you have no right
to complain that your husband is engaged elſewhere. But here comes the perſon we were ſpeaking of.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Ladies, as I come uninvited, I beg, if I intrude you will uſe the ſame freedom in turning me out again.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: I believe, ſir, it is near the time Mr. Loveleſs ſaid he would be at home. He talked of accepting of Lord Foppington's invitation to ſup at Sir Tunbelly Clumſey's.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: His Lordſhip has done me the honor to invite me alſo. If you'll let me eſcort you, I'll let you into a myſtery as me go, in which you muſt play a part when we arrive.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: But we have two hours yet to ſpare—the carriages are not ordered 'till eight—and it is not a five minutes drive. So, Couſin, let us keep the Colonel to play piquet with us, till Mr. Loveleſs comes home.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: As you pleaſe, Madam, but you know I have a letter to write.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Madam, you know you may command me, tho' I'm a very wretched gameſter.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p:
O, you play well enough to loſe your money, and that's all the ladies require—and
ſo without any more ceremony, let us go into the next room and call for cards and candles.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: So—thus far all's well—I have got into her dreſſing-room, and it being dusk, I think nobody has perceived me ſteal into the houſe. I heard Berinthia tell my wife ſhe had ſome particular letters to write this evening, before we went to Sir Tunbelly's, and here are the implements for correſpondence—how ſhall I muſter up aſſurance to ſhew myſelf when ſhe comes?—I think ſhe has given me encouragement—and to do my impudence juſtice, I have made the moſt of it.—I hear a door open and ſome one coming; if it ſhould be my wife, what the Devil ſhould I ſay?—I believe ſhe miſtruſts me, and by my life I don't deſerve her tenderneſs; however I am determined to reform, tho' not yet. Hah!—Berinthia—ſo I'll ſtep in here till I ſee what ſort of humour ſhe is in. [Goes into the Cloſet.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p:
Was ever ſo provoking a ſituation!—To think
I ſhould ſit and hear him compliment Amanda to my face!—I have loſt all patience with them both. I would not for ſomething have Loveleſs know what temper of mind they have piqued me into, yet I can't bear to leave them together. No—I'll put my papers away, and return, to diſappoint them. (Goes to the cloſet.) O Lord! a ghoſt! a ghoſt! a ghoſt!

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Peace, my Angel—it's no ghoſt—but one worth a hundred ſpirits.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: How, ſir, have you had the inſolence to preſume to—run in again—here's ſomebody coming.

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.p: O Lord, Ma'am, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: O Heav'ns I'm almoſt frightened out of my wits!—I thought verily I had ſeen a ghoſt, and 'twas nothing but a black hood pin'd againſt the wall.—You may go again, I am the fearfuleſt fool! [Exit Maid.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Is the coaſt clear?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: The coaſt clear!—Upon my word I wonder at your aſſurance!

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Why then you wonder before I have given you a proof of it. But where's my wife?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: At cards.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: With Townly.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Then we are ſafe enough.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: You are ſo!—Some huſbands would be of another mind were he at cards with their wives.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: And they'd be in the right on't too—but I dare truſt mine.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Indeed!—And ſhe, I doubt not, has the ſame confidence in you. Yet do you think ſhe'd be content to come and find you here?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: 'Egad, as you ſay, that's true—then for fear ſhe ſhould come, hadn't we better go into the next room out of her way?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: What—in the dark?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Aye—or with a light, which you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: You are certainly very impudent.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Nay then—let me conduct you, my Angel.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Hold, hold, you are miſtaken in your Angel, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: I hope not, for by this hand I ſwear.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Come, come, let go my hand, or I ſhall hate you, I'll cry out as I live.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Impoſſible!—you cannot be ſo cruel.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Ha!—here's ſome one coming—be gone inſtantly.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Will you promiſe to return if I remain here?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Never truſt myſelf in a room with you again while I live.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: But I have ſomething particular to communicate to you.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Well, well, before we go to Sir Tunbelly's I'll walk upon the lawn. If you are fond of a Moon-light evening, you will find me there.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: E'faith, they're coming here now.—I take you at your word. [Exit Loveleſs into the Cloſet.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p:
'Tis Amanda, as I live.—I hope ſhe has not
hheard s voice. Tho' I mean ſhe ſhould have er ſhare of jealouſy in turn.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Berinthia, why did you leave me?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: I thought I only ſpoil'd your party.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Since you have been gone, Townly has attempted to renew his importunities.—I muſt break with him—for I cannot venture to acquaint Mr. Loveleſs with his conduct.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: O no—Mr. Loveleſs muſtnt know of it by any means.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: O not for the world.—I wiſh, Berinthia, you would undertake to ſpeak to Townly on the ſubject.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Upon my word it would be a very pleaſant ſubject for me to talk to him on.—But come—let us go back,—and you may depend on't I'll not leave you together again, if I can help it.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p:
Soh—ſo!—a pretty piece of buſineſs I have over-heard—Townly makes love to my wife—and I'm not to know it for the world—I muſt
enquire into this—and, by Heav'n, if I find that Amanda has in the ſmalleſt degree—Yet what have I been at here?—O s'death! that's no rule.
sp.l: That wife alone, unſullied credit wins,
Whoſe virtues can atone her huſband's ſins;
Thus while the man has other nymphs in view,
It ſuits the woman to be doubly true.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: NOW, does ſhe mean to make a fool of me, or not?—I ſhan't wait much longer, for my wife will ſoon be enquiring for me to ſet out on our ſupping party.—Suſpence is at all times the devil—but of all modes of ſuſpence, the watching for a loitering miſtreſs is the worſt—but let me accuſe her no longer—ſhe approaches with one ſmile to o'erpay the anxiety of a year.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: O Berinthia, what a world of kindneſs are you in my debt!—had you ſtaid five minutes longer—

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: You would have been gone, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: (Aſide) Egad ſhe's right enough.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: And I aſſure you 'twas ten to one that I came at all. In ſhort, I begin to think you are too dangerous a Being to trifle with; and as I ſhall probably only make a fool of you at laſt, I believe we had better let matters reſt as they are.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS,
sp.p: You cannot mean it ſure?

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: No!—why do you think you are really ſo irreſiſtable, and maſter of ſo much addreſs, as to deprive a woman of her ſenſes in a few days acquaintance?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: O, no, Madam; 'tis only by your preſerving your ſenſes that I can hope to be admitted into your favour—your taſte, judgment, and diſcernment, are what I build my hopes on.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Very modeſt upon my word—and it certainly follows, that the greateſt proof I can give of my poſſeſſing thoſe qualities, would be my admiring Mr. Loveleſs!

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: O that were ſo cold a proof—

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: What ſhall I do more?—eſteem you?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: O, no—worſe and worſe.—Can you behold a man, whoſe every faculty your attractions have engroſſed—whoſe whole ſoul, as by enchantment, you have ſeiz'd on—can you ſee him tremble at your feet, and talk of ſo poor a return as your eſteem!

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: What more would you have me give to a married man?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: How doubly cruel to remind me of misfortunes!

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: A misfortune to be married to ſo charming a woman as Amanda!

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: I grant all her merit, but—'ſdeath, now ſee what you have done by talking of her—ſhe's here by all that's unlucky.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: O Ged, we had both better get out of the way, for I ſhould feel as aukward to meet her as you.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Aye—but if I miſtake not, I ſee Townly coming this way alſo—I muſt ſee a little into this matter. (ſteps aſide)

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: O, if that's your intention—I am no woman if ſuffer myſelf to be outdone in curioſity. (goes on the other ſide.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Mr. Loveleſs come home and walking on the awn!—I will not ſuffer him to walk ſo late, tho' perhaps it is to ſhew his neglect of me—Mr. Loveleſs—ha!—Townly again!—how I am perſecuted!

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Madam, you ſeem diſturbed!

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Sir, I have reaſon.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Whatever be the cauſe, I would to Heaven it were in my power to bear the pain, or to remove the malady.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Your interference can only add to my diſtreſs.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Ah! Madam, if it be the ſting of unrequited love you ſuffer from, ſeek for your remedy in revenge—weigh well the ſtrength and beauty of your charms, and rouſe up that ſpirit a woman ought to bear—diſdain the falſe embraces of a huſband—ſee at your feet a real lover—his zeal may give him title to your pity, altho' his merit cannot claim your love!

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: (Aſide.) So, ſo, very fine, e'faith!

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Why do you preſume to talk to me thus?—is this your friendſhip to Mr. Loveleſs?—I perceive you will compel me at laſt to acquaint him with your treachery.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: He could not upbraid me if you were—he deſerves it from me—for he has not been more falſe to you, than faithleſs to me.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: To you!

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Yes, Madam; the lady for whom he now deſerts thoſe charms which he was never worthy of, was mine by right; and I imagined too, by inclination—Yes, Madam, Berinthia, who now—

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Berinthia!—impoſſible!—

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: 'Tis true, or may I never merit your attention.—She is the deceitful ſorcereſs who now holds your huſband's heart in bondage.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: I will not believe it.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: By the faith of a true lover, I ſpeak from conviction.—This very day I ſaw them together, and overheard—

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Peace, Sir, I will not even liſten to ſuch ſlander—this is a poor device to work on my reſentment, to liſten to your inſidious addreſſes. No, Sir; though Mr. Loveleſs may be capable of error, I am convinced I cannot be deceived ſo groſsly in him, as to believe what you now report; and for Berinthia, you ſhould have fixed on ſome more probable perſon for my rival, than ſhe who is my relation, and my friend: for while I am myſelf free from guilt, I will never believe that love can beget injury, or confidence create ingratitude.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: If I do not prove this to you—

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: You never ſhall have an opportunity—from the artful manner in which you firſt ſhew'd yourſelf to me, I might have been led, as far as virtue permitted, to have thought you leſs criminal than unhappy—but this laſt unmanly artifice merits at once my reſentment and contempt. [Exit.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p:
Sure there's divinity about her; and ſhe has diſpenſed ſome portion of honor's light to me:
yet can I bear to loſe Berinthia without revenge or compenſation?—Perhaps ſhe is not ſo culpable as I thought her. I was miſtaken when I began to think lightly of Amanda's virtue, and may be in my cenſure of my Berinthia.—Surely I love her ſtill; for I feel I ſhould be happy to find myſelf in the wrong. [Exit.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Your ſervant, Mr. Loveleſs.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Your ſervant, Madam.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Pray, what do you think of this?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Truly, I don't know what to ſay.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Don't you think we ſteal forth two contemptible creatures?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Why tolerable—ſo I muſt confeſs.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: And do you conceive it poſſible for you ever to give Amanda the leaſt uneaſineſs again?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: No, I think we never ſhould, indeed.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: We!—why, monſter, you don't pretend that I ever entertain'd a thought.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p:
Why then, ſincerely, and honeſtly, Berinthia, there is ſomething in my wife's conduct which ſtrikes me ſo forcibly, that if it were not for ſhame,
and the fear of hurting you in her opinion, I ſwear I would follow her, confeſs my error, and truſt to her generoſity for forgiveneſs.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Nay, prithee don't let your reſpect for me prevent you; for as my object in trifling with you was nothing more than to pique Townly; and as I perceive he has been actuated by a ſimilar motive, you may depend on't I ſhall make no myſtery of the matter to him.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: By no means inform him—for tho' I may chuſe to paſs by his conduct without reſentment, how will he preſume to look me in the face again!

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: How will you preſume to look him in the face again?

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: He—who has dared to attempt the honour of my wife!

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: You—who have dared to attempt the honour of his miſtreſs!—Come, come, be ruled by me who affect more levity than I have, and don't think of anger in this cauſe. A Readineſs to reſent injuries, is a virtue only in thoſe who are ſlow to injure.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Then I will be ruled by you—and when you ſhall think proper to undeceive Townly, may your good qualities make as ſincere a convert of him, as Amanda's have of me. When truth's extended from us, then we own the robe of virtue is a ſecret habit.
sp.l: Could women but our ſecret counſels ſcan—
Could they but reach the deep reſerve of man—
To keep our love—they'd rate their virtue high—
They live together, and together die!

div.head: SCENE, Sir TUNBELLY'S HOUSE.
div.stage: Enter MISS HOYDEN, NURSE, and Y. FASHION.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: This quick diſpatch of the chaplain's I take ſo kindly, it ſhall give him claim to my favour as long as I live, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: And to mine too, I promiſe you.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: I moſt humbly thank your honors; and may your children ſwarm about you, like bees about a honey-comb.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: I'cod with all my heart—the more the merrier, I ſay—ha Nurſe?

div.stage: Enter LORY, taking Y. FASHION haſtily aſide.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: One word with you, for Heav'ns ſake.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: What the Devil's the matter?

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p:
Sir, your fortune's ruin'd, if you are not married—yonder's your brother, arrived with two coaches and ſix horſes, twenty footmen, and a coat
worth fourſcore pounds—ſo judge what will become of your Lady's heart.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Is he in the houſe yet?

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: No—they are capitulating with him at the gate—Sir Tunbelly luckily takes him for an impoſtor, and I have told him that we had heard of this plot before.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: That's right: (to Miſs) my dear, here's a troubleſome buſineſs my man tells me of, but don't be frighten'd, we ſhall be too hard for the rogue.—Here's an impudent fellow at the gate (not knowing I was come hither incognito) has taken my name upon him, in hopes to run away with you.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: O the brazen-faced varlet, it's well we are married, or may be we might never have been ſo.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: (Aſide) Egad like enough.—Prithee, Nurſe, run to Sir Tunbelly, and ſtop him from going to the gate before I ſpeak with him.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: An't pleaſe your honour, my Lady and I had beſt lock ourſelves up till the danger be over.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Do ſo, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Not ſo faſt—I won't be lock'd up any more, now I'm married.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Yes, pray, my dear do, till we have ſeiz'd this raſcal.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Nay, if you'll pray me, I'll do any thing. [Exit Miſs and Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: (To Lory.) Hark you, ſirrah, things are better than you imagine. The wedding's over.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: (Aſide.) The Devil it is, Sir!

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Not a word—all's ſafe—but Sir Tunbelly don't know it, nor muſt not, yet. So I am reſolved to brazen the buſineſs out, and have the pleaſure of turning the impoſtor upon his Lordſhip, which I believe may eaſily be done.

div.stage: Enter SIR TUNBELLY, and SERVANTS, armed. with clubs, pitch-forks, &c.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Did you ever hear, Sir, of ſo impudent an undertaking?

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Never, by the Maſs—but we'll tickle him, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: They tell me, Sir, he has a great many people with him, diſguiſed like ſervants.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Ay, ay, rogues enow—but we have maſter'd them.—We only fired a few ſhot over their heads, and the regiment ſcower'd in an inſtant.—Here, Tommas, bring in your priſoner.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p:
If you pleaſe, Sir Tunbelly, it will be beſt for
me not to confront the fellow yet, till you have heard how far his impudence will carry him.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: 'Egad, your Lordſhip is an ingenious perſon. Your Lordſhip then will pleaſe to ſtep aſide.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: (Aſide.) 'Fore Heaven I applaud my maſter's modeſty. (Exe. Young Faſhion and Lory.

div.stage: Enter SERVANTS, with LORD FOPPINGTON, diſarmed.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Come—bring him along, bring him along.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: What the pax do you mean, gentlemen, is it fair time that you are all drunk before ſupper?

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Drunk, ſirrah!—here's an impudent rogue for you. Drunk, or ſober, bully, I'm a Juſtice of the Peace, and know how to deal with ſtrollers.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Strollers!

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Aye, ſtrollers.—Come, give an account of yourſelf.—What's your name? Where do you live? Do you pay ſcot and lot? Come, are you a freeholder or a copyholder?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: And why doſt thou aſk me ſo many impertinent queſtions?

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Becauſe I'll make you anſwer 'em before I have done with you, you raſcal, you.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Before Gad, all the anſwers I can make to 'em, is, that you are a very extraordinary old fellow, ſtap my vitals!

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Nay, if thou are for joking with Deputy Lieutenants, we know how to deal with you—Here, draw a warrant for him immediately.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: A warrant!—What the Devil is't thou would'ſt be at, old gentleman?

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: I would be at you, ſiriah, (if my hands were not tied as a Magiſtrate) and with theſe two double fiſts beat your teeth down your throat you dog you.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: And why would'ſt thou ſpoil my face at that rate?

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: For your deſign to rob me of my daughter, villain.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Rab thee of your daughter! Now do I begin to believe I am in bed and aſleep, and that all this is but a dream. Prithee, old father, wilt thou give me leave to aſk thee one queſtion?

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: I can't tell whether I will or not, till I know what it is.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Why then it is, whether thou didſt not write to my Lord Foppington to come down and marry thy daughter?

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Yes, marry did I, and my Lord Foppington is come down, and ſhall marry my daughter before ſhe's a day older.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Now give me thy hand, old dad, I thought we ſhould underſtand one another at laſt.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: This fellow's mad—here, bind him hand and foot. [They bind him.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Nay, prithee Knight, leave fooling, thy jeſt begins to grow dull.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Bind him, I ſay—he's mad—bread and water, a dark room, and a whip, may bring him to his ſenſes again.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Prithee, Sir Tunbelly, why ſhould you take ſuch an averſion to the freedom of my addreſs, as to ſuffer the raſcals thus to ſkewer down my arms like a rabbit? 'Egad, if I don't waken quickly, by all that I can ſee, this is like to prove one of the moſt impertinent dreams that ever I dreamt in my life. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: (Going up to him.) Is this he that would have run away with me? Fough! how he ſtinks of ſweets!—Pray, father, let him be dragged thro' the horſe-pond.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON,
sp.p: (Aſide.) This muſt be my wife, by her natural inclination to her huſband.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Pray, father, what do you intend to do with him—hang him?

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: That, at leaſt, child.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Aye, and it's e'en too good for him too.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Madame la Governante, I preſume; hitherto this appears to me to be one of the moſt extraordinary families that ever man of quality match'd into.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: What's become of my Lord, daughter?

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: He's juſt coming, Sir.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: (Aſide.) My Lord!—What does he mean by that, now?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Stap my vitals, Tam, now the dream's out.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Is this the fellow, Sir, that deſign'd to trick me of your daughter?

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: This is he, my Lord; how do you like him? is not he a pretty fellow to get a fortune?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: I find by his dreſs, he thought your daughter might be taken with a beau.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p:
O gemini! Is this a beau? Let me ſee him again.
Ha! I find a beau is no ſuch ugly thing, neither.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: 'Egad, ſhe'll be in love with him preſently.—I'll e'en have him ſent away to gaol. (To Lord Fop.) Sir, tho' your undertaking ſhews you a perſon of no extraordinary modeſty, I ſuppoſe you ha'n't confidence enough to expect much favour from me.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINOTON.
sp.p: Strike me dumb, Tam, thou art a very impudent fellow.

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Look; if the varlot has not the frontery to call his Lordſhip, plain Thomas.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Come, is the warrant writ?

sp.speaker: CHAPLAIN.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Hold, one moment.—Pray gentlemen—my Lord Foppington, ſhall I beg one word with your Lordſhip?

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: O, ho, it's my Lord, with him now; ſee how afflictions will humble folks.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, don't let him whiſper too cloſe, leſt he bite your ear off.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p:
I am not altogether ſo hungry as your Ladyſhip is pleaſed to imagine. (To Y. Faſhion.) Look you, Tam, I am ſenſible I have not been ſo kind to you as I ought, but I hope you'll forgive what's paſt, and except of the five thouſand pounds I
offer. Thou may'ſt live in extreme ſplendor with it, ſtap my vitals!

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: It's a much eaſier matter to prevent a diſeaſe, than to cure it. A quarter of that ſum would have ſecured your miſtreſs, twice as much won't redeem her. [Leaving him.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Well, what ſays he?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Only the raſcal offered me a bribe to let him go.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Aye, he ſhall go, with a halter to him—lead on, Conſtable.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Sir, here is Muſter Loveleſs, and Muſter Colonel Townly, and ſome ladies, to wait on you.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: (Aſide.) So, Sir, What will you do now?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Be quiet—they are in the plot. (To Sir Tunbelly.) Only a few friends, Sir Tunbelly, whom I wiſh'd to introduce to you.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Thou art the moſt impudent fellow, Tam, that ever Nature yet brought into the world. Sir Tunbelly, ſtrike me ſpeechleſs, but theſe are my friends and my gueſts, and they will ſoon inform thee, whether I am the true Lord Foppington or not.

div.stage: Enter LOVELESS, TOWNLY, AMANDA, and BERINTHIA.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: So, gentlemen, this is friendly; I rejoice to ſee you.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: My Lord, we are fortunate to be the witneſſes of your Lordſhip's happineſs.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: But your Lordſhip will do us the honour to introduce us to Sir Tunbelly Clumſey?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: And us to your Lady.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Ged take me, but they are all in a ſtory.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you do me great honour; my Lord Foppington's friends will ever be welcome to me and mine.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: My love, let me introduce you to theſe ladies.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: By goles, they look ſo fine and ſo ſtiff, I am almoſt aſham'd to come nigh 'em.

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: A moſt engaging lady, indeed!

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Thank ye, Ma'am!

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: And I doubt not will ſoon diſtinguiſh herſelf in the Beau Monde.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Where is that?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: You'll ſoon learn, my dear.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: But, Lord Foppington—

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Sir! I was not addreſſing myſelf to you, Sir; pray who is this gentleman? He ſeems rather in a ſingular predicament.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!—So, theſe are your friends and your gueſts, ha, my adventurer?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: I am ſtruck dumb with their impudence, and cannot poſitively ſay whether I ſhall ever ſpeak again or not.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Why, Sir, this modeſt gentleman wanted to paſs himſelf upon me for Lord Foppington, and carry off my daughter.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: A likely plot to ſucceed, truly, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: As Gad ſhall judge me, Loveleſs, I did not expect this from thee; come, prithee confeſs the joke; tell Sir Tunbelly that I am the real Lord Foppington, who yeſterday made love to thy wife; was honour'd by her with a ſlap on the face, and afterward pink'd thro' the body by thee.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: A likely ſtory, truly, that a Peer wou'd behave thus!

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: A curious fellow indeed! that wou'd ſcandalize the character he wants to aſſume; but what will you do with him, Sir Tunbelly?

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Commit him certainly, unleſs the bride and bridegroom chuſe to pardon him.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Bride and bridegroom! For Gad's ſake, Sir Tunbelly, 'tis tarture to me to hear you call 'em ſo.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: Why, you ugly thing, what would you have him call us? dog and cat!

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: By no means, Miſs; for that ſounds ten times more like man and wife, than t'other.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: A precious rogue this, to come a wooing!

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: There are ſome more gentlefolks below, to wait upon Lord Foppington.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: S'death, Tom, what will you do now?

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Now, Sir Tunbelly, here are witneſſes, who I believe are not corrupted.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Peace, fellow!—Wou'd your Lordſhip chuſe to have your gueſts ſhewn here, or ſhall they wait till we come to 'em?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: I believe, Sir Tunbelly, we had better not have theſe viſitors here yet; 'egad, all muſt out! [Aſide.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Confeſs, confeſs, we'll ſtand by you.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Nay, Sir Tunbelly, I inſiſt on your calling evidence on both ſides, and if I do not prove that fellow an impoſtor—

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Brother, I will ſave you the trouble, by now confeſſing, that I am not what I have paſſed myſelf for;—Sir Tunbelly, I am a gentleman, and I flatter myſelf a man of character; but 'tis with great pride I aſſure, I am not Lord Foppington.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Oun's!—what's this!—an impoſtor!—a cheat!—fire and faggots, Sir!—if you are not Lord Foppington, who the Devil are you?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Sir, the beſt of my condition is, I am your ſon in-law, and the worſt of it is, I am brother to that noble Peer.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Impudent to the laſt!

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: My ſon-in-law! Not yet, I hope?

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir, thanks to the goodneſs of your Chaplain, and the kind offices of this old gentle woman.

sp.speaker: LORY.
sp.p: 'Tis true, indeed, Sir; I gave your daughter away, and Mrs. Nurſe, here, was clerk.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Knock that raſcal down!—But ſpeak, Jezabel, how's this?

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Alas, your honour, forgive me!—I have been overreach'd in this buſineſs as well as you; your Worſhip knows, if the wedding dinner had been ready, you would have given her away with your own hands.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: But how durſt you do this without acquainting me!

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: Alas, if your Worſhip had ſeen how the poor thing begg'd and pray'd, and clung and twin'd about me like ivy round an old wall, you wou'd ſay I who had nurs'd it and rear'd it, muſt have had a heart of ſtone to refuſe it.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Ouns! I ſhall go mad! Unlooſe my Lord there, you ſcoundrels!

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Why, when theſe gentlemen are at leiſure, I ſhou'd be glad to congratulate you on your ſon-in-law, with a little more freedom of addreſs.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: 'Egad, tho'—I don't ſee which is to be my husband, after all.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Come, come, Sir Tunbelly, a man of your underſtanding muſt perceive, that an affair of this kind is not to be mended by anger and reproaches.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p:
Take my word for it, Sir Tunbelly, you are
only tricked into a ſon-in-law you may be proud of; my friend, Tom Faſhion, is as honeſt a fellow as ever breath'd.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: That he is, depend on't, and will hunt or drink with you moſt affectionately; be generous, old boy, and forgive them.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Never—the huſſey:—when I had ſet my heart on getting her a title!

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Now, Sir Tunbelly, that I am untruſs'd, give me leave to thank thee for the very extraordinary reception I have met with in thy damn'd, execrable manſion, and at the ſame time to aſſure you, that of all the bumpkins and blockheads I have had the misfortune to meet with, thou art the moſt obſtinate and egregious, ſtrike me ugly!

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: What's this!—Ouns! I believe you are both rogues alike!

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: No, Sir Tunbelly, thou wilt find to thy unſpeakable mortification, that I am the real Lord Foppington, who was to have diſgraced myſelf by an alliance with a clod; and that thou haſt match'd thy girl to a beggarly younger brother of mine, whoſe title deeds might be contain'd in thy tobacco-box.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Puppy, puppy!—I might prevent their being beggars if I choſe it;—for I cou'd give 'em as good a rent-roll as your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: Well ſaid, Sir Tunbelly.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Aye, old fellow, but you will not do it; for that would be acting like a Chriſtian, and thou art a thorough barbarian, ſtap my vitals.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Udzookers! Now ſix ſuch words more, and I'll forgive them directly.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: 'Slife, Sir Tunbelly, you ſhou'd do it, and bleſs yourſelf; ladies what ſay you?

sp.speaker: AMANDA.
sp.p: Good Sir Tunbelly, you muſt conſent.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Come, you have been young yourſelf, Sir Tunbelly.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: Well, then, if I muſt, I muſt;—but turn that ſneering Lord out, however; and let me be revenged on ſomebody; but firſt, look whether I am a barbarian, or not; there, children, I join your hands, and when I'm in a better humour, I'll give you my bleſſing.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: Nobly done, Sir Tunbelly; and we ſhall ſee you dance at a grandſon's wedding, yet.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: By goles tho', I don't underſtand this; what, an't I to be a lady after all? only plain Mrs.—What's my huſband's name, Nurſe?

sp.speaker: NURSE.
sp.p: 'Squire Faſhion.

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: 'Squire, is he?—Well, that's better than nothing.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Now will I put on a Philoſophic air, and ſhew theſe people, that it is not poſſible to put a man of my quality out of countenance. Dear, Tam, ſince things are thus fallen out, prythee give me leave to wiſh thee joy; I do it de bon coeur, ſtrike me dumb! You have married into a family of great politeneſs and uncommon elegance of manners; and your bride appears to be a lady beautiful in perſon, modeſt in her deportment, refined in her ſentiments, and of nice morality, ſplit my windpipe!

sp.speaker: MISS.
sp.p: By goles, huſband, break his bones, if he calls me names.

sp.speaker: Y. FASHION.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip may keep up your ſpirits with your grimace, if you pleaſe, I ſhall ſupport mine by Sir Tunbelly's favour, with this lady, and three thouſand pounds a year.

sp.speaker: LD. FOPPINGTON.
sp.p: Well, adieu, Tam; ladies, I kiſs your hands; Sir Tunbelly, I ſhall now quit thy den, but while I retain my arms, I ſhall remember thou art a ſavage, ſtap my vitals! [Exit.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: By the maſs, 'tis well he's gone, for I ſhou'd ha' been provok'd by and by, to ha' dun'un a miſchief;—Well, if this is a Lord, I think Hoyden has luck o' her ſide, in troth!

sp.speaker: TOWNLY.
sp.p: She has, indeed, Sir Tunbelly, but I hear the fiddles; his Lordſhip, I know, had provided 'em.

sp.speaker: LOVELESS.
sp.p: O, a dance, and a bottle, Sir Tunbelly, by all means.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: I had forgot the company below; well, what—we muſt be merry then, ha?—and dance and drink, ha?—Well, 'fore George, you ſhan't ſay I do things by halves; ſon-in-law there looks like a hearty rogue, ſo we'll have a night of it; and which of theſe gay ladies will be the old man's partner, ha?—Ecod, I don't know how I came to be in ſo good a humour.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Well, Sir Tunbelly, my friend and I both will endeavour to keep you ſo; you have done a generous action, and are entitled to our attention; and if you ſhou'd be at a loſs to divert your new gueſts, we will aſſiſt you to relate to them the plot of your daughter's marriage, and his Lordſhip's deſerved mortification, a ſubject which, perhaps, may afford no bad evening's entertainment.

sp.speaker: SIR TUNBELLY.
sp.p: 'Ecod, with all my heart; tho' I am a main bungler at a long ſtory.

sp.speaker: BERINTHIA.
sp.p: Never fear, we will aſſiſt you, if the tale is judged worth being repeated; but of this you may be aſſured, that while the intention is evidently to pleaſe, Britiſh auditors will ever be indulgent to the errors of the performance.
